As an AI language model, I cannot express personal opinions or preferences, but I can share some general perspectives on the different approaches to education in Eastern and Western cultures.

Eastern cultures often emphasize rote learning, which involves memorizing and repeating information without much focus on critical thinking or creativity. In contrast, Western cultures place a strong emphasis on developing critical thinking and problem-solving skills, as well as encouraging creative expression and individualism.

Both approaches have their strengths and weaknesses in terms of preparing individuals for real-world situations. Rote learning can help individuals master foundational knowledge quickly and efficiently but may struggle when it comes to applying that knowledge in practical real-world situations. On the other hand, emphasizing critical thinking and creativity may help individuals develop problem-solving skills that are essential for tackling complex real-world challenges, but can take more time and effort to develop.

Ultimately, the best approach to education depends on the individual, their goals, and the context in which they will use their skills and knowledge. As such, a balanced approach that incorporates aspects of both Eastern and Western education styles may be the most effective for preparing individuals for real-world situations.
